Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Aid to Environment
Gender Equality

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The support has concerned a four year period with the first three years (2014-2016) upheld through the Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support 2011-2016 and the final fourth year (2017) being part of the new strategy for the period 2017-2021). The majority of Sida HUM's contribution has been for the UNICEF HAC:s (Humanitarian Assistance for Children) and have been treated as humanitarian country programme funds (unearmarked) while a few programmes have been earmarket to ceratin thematic areas within the HAC:s. The prioritisation has been led by Sida HUM through its HCA (Humanitarian Crises Analysis) processes on an annual basis. UNICEF provides annual CER:s reporting for each context on a country basis reporting on what has been achieved compared to each HAC. In addition to that Sida receives the global humanitarian annual report of UNICEF and a two-pager for each financed context for a more detailed information on what exactly the Swedish funds have been directed to. For 2014, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 177.5 MSEK which contributed to some of the following worldwide humanitarian results (as per the annual global humanitarian report):- 1.8 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (70 per cent of planned target);- 16 million children were vaccinated against measles (81 percent of target);- 13 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (77 per cent oftarget);- 1.8 million children (66 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 2 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (58 per cent oftarget); and- With the Ebola outbreak in 2014, some of UNlCEF'S achievements included: established and supported morethan 50 Community Care Centres and rapid isolation facilities with a bed capacity of 500; 30 000 children affectedby the outbreak beneitted from psycho-social support; 4 100 metric tonnes (MT) of Ebola related commoditieswere shipped; more than 50 000 community volunteers, health workers, religious Ieaders and youth weremobilized; 1 400 Community Watch Committees were established; and 1 million children received educationthrough remote programming while schools were closed. Support from Sida has contributed to reaching the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts in the world. For 2015, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 184 MSEK. Sida supported UNICEF with funding of 16 countries and one region (i.e the floods in Malawi and Mozambique, earthquake in Nepal and the deteriorating situations in CAR, South Sudan, Yemen, Syria, Nigeria and Iraq). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during 2015 for which the Swedish financing has contributed towards are:- 2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (69 per cent of planned target);- 1.3 million children were vaccinated against measles (62 per cent of target);- 22.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing andcooking (94 per cent of target);- 2 million children (74 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal andinformal (45 per cent of target); and- Since the Ebola outbreak in 2014, UNICEF'S achievements in Sierra Leone. Liberiaand Guinea included:- 191,200 children received psychosocial support;- More than 3.6 million households were reached with interpersonal communications and skills training on Ebola prevention;- More than 8,000 metric tonnes of supplies delivered in the largest supply operations in UNlCEF'S history; and- 64 community care centres were established.Some of UNICEF'S other achievments in 2015 include the following:- The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was enhanced by recruiting eight Emergency Response Team (ERI) members. In total, 12 field offices were supported by this team with some 500 days of ERT deployments throughout the year.- UNICEF's lmmediate Response Team (ERT) members, who are the experts in key programme and operational areas, were deployed 20 times for 783 days. Furthermore, the emergency simulation training was rolled out in mid-2015 with a total of 28 ERT and seven ERT members were trained and prepared for deployment as surge staff within 24-48 hours.- The UNICEF Emergency Programme Fond (EPF) which is a revolving fund that the organization disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis. In 2016, some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during the first ten months included:-2.2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (66 per cent of planned target);- 9.4 million children were vaccinated against measles (48 per cent of target);- 13.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (85 per cent of target);- 2.3 million children (70 per cent of target) recieved psycho-social support; and- 6.4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (81 per cent of target). Five major emergencies required organization-wide mobilization which included the continuing conflicts in South Sudan and Yemen; the escalating violence in Iraq; the protracted crisis in the Syrian Arab Republic and neighbouring refugee-hosting countries; and the unfolding humanitarian situation in north-east Nigeria. Regional offices were also responsible for overseeing the Central African Republic, Haiti and Lake Chad basin. In all cases, UNlCEF's infrastructure played a vital role in supporting country responses. Some of UNICEF's other achievements in 2016 include the following:1. The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was significantly enhanced with the recruitment of an additional ERT-members in 2016. Twelve ERT members undertook 37 missions to 17 countries and three regional offices, totaling 2,356 days between January and December 2016.2. Standby partners responded to a significant source of capacity, deploying 213 personnel to country offices in 2016 through agreements with 30 organizations. Forty-one per cent of these deployments supported Level 2 and Level 3 emergencies.3. UNICEF has prioritized strengthening its preparedness systems through the development of the Preparedness Procedure and associated guidance for country offices, including mandatory minimum standards. In addition, the new online Emergency Preparedness Platform has been designed to support planning and monitoring.4. UNICEF launched the Health Emergencies Preparedness Initiative to strengthen organizational capacity to respond predictably to public health emergencies, in close collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization. This initiative was a result of the lessons learnt from Ebola crisis.5. For the first time, in partnership with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and respective National Societies in 13 countrics, UNICEF developed joint programmes aimed at strengthening community resilience. Innovative tools such as U-Report are being used to engage communities and scale-up programmes.6. In an effort to strengthen capacity, UNICEF and the World Food Programme developed their first-ever joint Level 3 emergency response situation with 22 personnel from each agency. The exercise improved agencies' understandings of the mechanisms, policy and guidance to better prepare for deployment into a system-wide response.7. The Emergency Programme Fond - a revolving fond that UNICEF disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis, before donor resources are available - distributed USD 26 million to 14 country offices and three regional offices in 2016.The contribution to UNICEF cluring 2016 and from previous years has contributed to reaching some of the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts worldwide. In 2017, UNICEF and partners responded to 337 humanitarian situations of various scales in 102 countries. UNICEF focused its humanitarian action on saving lives, protecting rights and addressing the underlying causes of vulnerabilities to crises. More than half (55 per cent) of all country-level spending in 2017 supported humanitarian action. The organization continued to leverage its long-standing comparative advantage for humanitarian action of having a field presence before, during and after emergencies; delivering a multi-sector approach and collaborating various actors (e.g. government, civil society and the private sector). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF in 2017 include:- 3.0 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (83 per cent of planned target);- 18 million children were vaccinated against measles (74 percent of target);- 32.7 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (95 per cent of target);- 3.5 million children (89 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 8.8 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (73 per cent of target);- 46,000 children (81 percent of target) HIV-positive pregnant women continued anti-retroviral therapy; and- 1 million people benefitted from humanitarian cash transfers/cash-based support. There has been a good collaboration with UNICEF both through the focal points at UNICEF headquarters (people have changed during the four years) and EMOPS (Emergency Operations) where Manual Fontaine has been the head of unit. The contact person at Sida for UNICEF has been important for Sida HUM to liaise with and the person has changed during the four years. The contact with Swedish MFA has been handled by the Sida focal person mainly. The id number for the support was 5204046801 during 2014-2016 during which the old Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support led the work (2011-2016) and for 2017 when a new Humanitarian Strategy was in place the id number changed to 5204046802. The four narrative reports and financial reports under this contribution have been received in time. These include the Consolidated Emergency Reports/CERs (including the brief narrative of the Swedish contribution and Funds utilization reports (FUR), and Financial statement. UNICEF has repaid the balances from the annual support by sharing a letter the following year informing about the balance ans submitting the final financial report. The first repayment for 2013 and 2014 was reported on the previous support not part of these four years under this statement of conclusion (USD 193 820). The following repayments were reported on this contribution (October 2017, September 2019, and December 2019). The full balance of 8 401 990 SEK have thereby been accounted for by UNICEF and reflected in Planit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNICEF Humanitarian support to country programs 2014-2017

description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med UNICEF om bidrag till humanitära insatser för humanitära program 2014-2017, enligt insatsregeln 3.11.3. Beslutet gäller för ett fjärde och sista tilläggsår av ett ursprungligen 3-årigt avtal.
Sida förmedlar stöd till UNICEF baserat på FN appeller samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEFs humanitära program öronmärkt för aktiviteter på landnivå. Sida finansierar de humanitära appellerna per land enligt behoven som finns enligt UNICEFs handlingsplan (HAC) för varje kris. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en viktig aktör och genom detta stöd kommer organisationen att kunna fortsätta att ge livräddande stöd till de mest utsatta grupper som barn och kvinnor i humanitära krissituationer.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser för att stödja samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för barnskydd och könsbaserad våld. Stödet kommer att omfatta såväl nya akuta humanitära situationer som ännu inte har inträffat, som pågående eller eskalerande kriser.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i sin tur i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för programmen.Mot denna bakgrund gör Sida bedömningen att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2017. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik i form av att bygga upp lager i regionala depåer och en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, varvid UNICEF måste vara förberedda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida Humanitära Enheten har för närvarandet ett 3-årigt avtal med UNICEF. Avsikten med detta beslut är att förlänga nuvarande avtal med ett år som täcker perioden 2017 vilket kommer att vara det sista året under detta avtal. För år 2018 planeras ett nytt 4-årigt avtal med UNICEF i syfte att komma i fas med organisationens planerade strategiska plan för 2018-2021.
Stödet till UNICEF för 2017 innefattar två kategorier:
A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

Stödet till UNICEF för 2017 innefattar två kategorier:
A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

description.narrative: The support has concerned a four year period with the first three years (2014-2016) upheld through the Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support 2011-2016 and the final fourth year (2017) being part of the new strategy for the period 2017-2021). The majority of Sida HUM's contribution has been for the UNICEF HAC:s (Humanitarian Assistance for Children) and have been treated as humanitarian country programme funds (unearmarked) while a few programmes have been earmarket to ceratin thematic areas within the HAC:s. The prioritisation has been led by Sida HUM through its HCA (Humanitarian Crises Analysis) processes on an annual basis. UNICEF provides annual CER:s reporting for each context on a country basis reporting on what has been achieved compared to each HAC. In addition to that Sida receives the global humanitarian annual report of UNICEF and a two-pager for each financed context for a more detailed information on what exactly the Swedish funds have been directed to. For 2014, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 177.5 MSEK which contributed to some of the following worldwide humanitarian results (as per the annual global humanitarian report):- 1.8 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (70 per cent of planned target);- 16 million children were vaccinated against measles (81 percent of target);- 13 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (77 per cent oftarget);- 1.8 million children (66 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 2 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (58 per cent oftarget); and- With the Ebola outbreak in 2014, some of UNlCEF'S achievements included: established and supported morethan 50 Community Care Centres and rapid isolation facilities with a bed capacity of 500; 30 000 children affectedby the outbreak beneitted from psycho-social support; 4 100 metric tonnes (MT) of Ebola related commoditieswere shipped; more than 50 000 community volunteers, health workers, religious Ieaders and youth weremobilized; 1 400 Community Watch Committees were established; and 1 million children received educationthrough remote programming while schools were closed. Support from Sida has contributed to reaching the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts in the world. For 2015, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 184 MSEK. Sida supported UNICEF with funding of 16 countries and one region (i.e the floods in Malawi and Mozambique, earthquake in Nepal and the deteriorating situations in CAR, South Sudan, Yemen, Syria, Nigeria and Iraq). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during 2015 for which the Swedish financing has contributed towards are:- 2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (69 per cent of planned target);- 1.3 million children were vaccinated against measles (62 per cent of target);- 22.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing andcooking (94 per cent of target);- 2 million children (74 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal andinformal (45 per cent of target); and- Since the Ebola outbreak in 2014, UNICEF'S achievements in Sierra Leone. Liberiaand Guinea included:- 191,200 children received psychosocial support;- More than 3.6 million households were reached with interpersonal communications and skills training on Ebola prevention;- More than 8,000 metric tonnes of supplies delivered in the largest supply operations in UNlCEF'S history; and- 64 community care centres were established.Some of UNICEF'S other achievments in 2015 include the following:- The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was enhanced by recruiting eight Emergency Response Team (ERI) members. In total, 12 field offices were supported by this team with some 500 days of ERT deployments throughout the year.- UNICEF's lmmediate Response Team (ERT) members, who are the experts in key programme and operational areas, were deployed 20 times for 783 days. Furthermore, the emergency simulation training was rolled out in mid-2015 with a total of 28 ERT and seven ERT members were trained and prepared for deployment as surge staff within 24-48 hours.- The UNICEF Emergency Programme Fond (EPF) which is a revolving fund that the organization disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis. In 2016, some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during the first ten months included:-2.2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (66 per cent of planned target);- 9.4 million children were vaccinated against measles (48 per cent of target);- 13.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (85 per cent of target);- 2.3 million children (70 per cent of target) recieved psycho-social support; and- 6.4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (81 per cent of target). Five major emergencies required organization-wide mobilization which included the continuing conflicts in South Sudan and Yemen; the escalating violence in Iraq; the protracted crisis in the Syrian Arab Republic and neighbouring refugee-hosting countries; and the unfolding humanitarian situation in north-east Nigeria. Regional offices were also responsible for overseeing the Central African Republic, Haiti and Lake Chad basin. In all cases, UNlCEF's infrastructure played a vital role in supporting country responses. Some of UNICEF's other achievements in 2016 include the following:1. The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was significantly enhanced with the recruitment of an additional ERT-members in 2016. Twelve ERT members undertook 37 missions to 17 countries and three regional offices, totaling 2,356 days between January and December 2016.2. Standby partners responded to a significant source of capacity, deploying 213 personnel to country offices in 2016 through agreements with 30 organizations. Forty-one per cent of these deployments supported Level 2 and Level 3 emergencies.3. UNICEF has prioritized strengthening its preparedness systems through the development of the Preparedness Procedure and associated guidance for country offices, including mandatory minimum standards. In addition, the new online Emergency Preparedness Platform has been designed to support planning and monitoring.4. UNICEF launched the Health Emergencies Preparedness Initiative to strengthen organizational capacity to respond predictably to public health emergencies, in close collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization. This initiative was a result of the lessons learnt from Ebola crisis.5. For the first time, in partnership with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and respective National Societies in 13 countrics, UNICEF developed joint programmes aimed at strengthening community resilience. Innovative tools such as U-Report are being used to engage communities and scale-up programmes.6. In an effort to strengthen capacity, UNICEF and the World Food Programme developed their first-ever joint Level 3 emergency response situation with 22 personnel from each agency. The exercise improved agencies' understandings of the mechanisms, policy and guidance to better prepare for deployment into a system-wide response.7. The Emergency Programme Fond - a revolving fond that UNICEF disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis, before donor resources are available - distributed USD 26 million to 14 country offices and three regional offices in 2016.The contribution to UNICEF cluring 2016 and from previous years has contributed to reaching some of the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts worldwide. In 2017, UNICEF and partners responded to 337 humanitarian situations of various scales in 102 countries. UNICEF focused its humanitarian action on saving lives, protecting rights and addressing the underlying causes of vulnerabilities to crises. More than half (55 per cent) of all country-level spending in 2017 supported humanitarian action. The organization continued to leverage its long-standing comparative advantage for humanitarian action of having a field presence before, during and after emergencies; delivering a multi-sector approach and collaborating various actors (e.g. government, civil society and the private sector). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF in 2017 include:- 3.0 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (83 per cent of planned target);- 18 million children were vaccinated against measles (74 percent of target);- 32.7 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (95 per cent of target);- 3.5 million children (89 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 8.8 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (73 per cent of target);- 46,000 children (81 percent of target) HIV-positive pregnant women continued anti-retroviral therapy; and- 1 million people benefitted from humanitarian cash transfers/cash-based support. There has been a good collaboration with UNICEF both through the focal points at UNICEF headquarters (people have changed during the four years) and EMOPS (Emergency Operations) where Manual Fontaine has been the head of unit. The contact person at Sida for UNICEF has been important for Sida HUM to liaise with and the person has changed during the four years. The contact with Swedish MFA has been handled by the Sida focal person mainly. The id number for the support was 5204046801 during 2014-2016 during which the old Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support led the work (2011-2016) and for 2017 when a new Humanitarian Strategy was in place the id number changed to 5204046802. The four narrative reports and financial reports under this contribution have been received in time. These include the Consolidated Emergency Reports/CERs (including the brief narrative of the Swedish contribution and Funds utilization reports (FUR), and Financial statement. UNICEF has repaid the balances from the annual support by sharing a letter the following year informing about the balance ans submitting the final financial report. The first repayment for 2013 and 2014 was reported on the previous support not part of these four years under this statement of conclusion (USD 193 820). The following repayments were reported on this contribution (October 2017, September 2019, and December 2019). The full balance of 8 401 990 SEK have thereby been accounted for by UNICEF and reflected in Planit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNICEF Humanitarian support to country programs 2014-2017

description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med UNICEF om bidrag till humanitära insatser för humanitära program 2014-2017, enligt insatsregeln 3.11.3. Beslutet gäller för ett fjärde och sista tilläggsår av ett ursprungligen 3-årigt avtal.
Sida förmedlar stöd till UNICEF baserat på FN appeller samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEFs humanitära program öronmärkt för aktiviteter på landnivå. Sida finansierar de humanitära appellerna per land enligt behoven som finns enligt UNICEFs handlingsplan (HAC) för varje kris. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en viktig aktör och genom detta stöd kommer organisationen att kunna fortsätta att ge livräddande stöd till de mest utsatta grupper som barn och kvinnor i humanitära krissituationer.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser för att stödja samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för barnskydd och könsbaserad våld. Stödet kommer att omfatta såväl nya akuta humanitära situationer som ännu inte har inträffat, som pågående eller eskalerande kriser.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i sin tur i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för programmen.Mot denna bakgrund gör Sida bedömningen att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2017. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik i form av att bygga upp lager i regionala depåer och en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, varvid UNICEF måste vara förberedda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida Humanitära Enheten har för närvarandet ett 3-årigt avtal med UNICEF. Avsikten med detta beslut är att förlänga nuvarande avtal med ett år som täcker perioden 2017 vilket kommer att vara det sista året under detta avtal. För år 2018 planeras ett nytt 4-årigt avtal med UNICEF i syfte att komma i fas med organisationens planerade strategiska plan för 2018-2021.
Stödet till UNICEF för 2017 innefattar två kategorier:
A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för barnskydd och könsbaserad våld. Stödet kommer att omfatta såväl nya akuta humanitära situationer som ännu inte har inträffat, som pågående eller eskalerande kriser.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i sin tur i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för programmen.Mot denna bakgrund gör Sida bedömningen att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2017. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik i form av att bygga upp lager i regionala depåer och en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, varvid UNICEF måste vara förberedda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida Humanitära Enheten har för närvarandet ett 3-årigt avtal med UNICEF. Avsikten med detta beslut är att förlänga nuvarande avtal med ett år som täcker perioden 2017 vilket kommer att vara det sista året under detta avtal. För år 2018 planeras ett nytt 4-årigt avtal med UNICEF i syfte att komma i fas med organisationens planerade strategiska plan för 2018-2021.
Stödet till UNICEF för 2017 innefattar två kategorier:
A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

description.narrative: The support has concerned a four year period with the first three years (2014-2016) upheld through the Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support 2011-2016 and the final fourth year (2017) being part of the new strategy for the period 2017-2021). The majority of Sida HUM's contribution has been for the UNICEF HAC:s (Humanitarian Assistance for Children) and have been treated as humanitarian country programme funds (unearmarked) while a few programmes have been earmarket to ceratin thematic areas within the HAC:s. The prioritisation has been led by Sida HUM through its HCA (Humanitarian Crises Analysis) processes on an annual basis. UNICEF provides annual CER:s reporting for each context on a country basis reporting on what has been achieved compared to each HAC. In addition to that Sida receives the global humanitarian annual report of UNICEF and a two-pager for each financed context for a more detailed information on what exactly the Swedish funds have been directed to. For 2014, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 177.5 MSEK which contributed to some of the following worldwide humanitarian results (as per the annual global humanitarian report):- 1.8 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (70 per cent of planned target);- 16 million children were vaccinated against measles (81 percent of target);- 13 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (77 per cent oftarget);- 1.8 million children (66 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 2 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (58 per cent oftarget); and- With the Ebola outbreak in 2014, some of UNlCEF'S achievements included: established and supported morethan 50 Community Care Centres and rapid isolation facilities with a bed capacity of 500; 30 000 children affectedby the outbreak beneitted from psycho-social support; 4 100 metric tonnes (MT) of Ebola related commoditieswere shipped; more than 50 000 community volunteers, health workers, religious Ieaders and youth weremobilized; 1 400 Community Watch Committees were established; and 1 million children received educationthrough remote programming while schools were closed. Support from Sida has contributed to reaching the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts in the world. For 2015, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 184 MSEK. Sida supported UNICEF with funding of 16 countries and one region (i.e the floods in Malawi and Mozambique, earthquake in Nepal and the deteriorating situations in CAR, South Sudan, Yemen, Syria, Nigeria and Iraq). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during 2015 for which the Swedish financing has contributed towards are:- 2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (69 per cent of planned target);- 1.3 million children were vaccinated against measles (62 per cent of target);- 22.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing andcooking (94 per cent of target);- 2 million children (74 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal andinformal (45 per cent of target); and- Since the Ebola outbreak in 2014, UNICEF'S achievements in Sierra Leone. Liberiaand Guinea included:- 191,200 children received psychosocial support;- More than 3.6 million households were reached with interpersonal communications and skills training on Ebola prevention;- More than 8,000 metric tonnes of supplies delivered in the largest supply operations in UNlCEF'S history; and- 64 community care centres were established.Some of UNICEF'S other achievments in 2015 include the following:- The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was enhanced by recruiting eight Emergency Response Team (ERI) members. In total, 12 field offices were supported by this team with some 500 days of ERT deployments throughout the year.- UNICEF's lmmediate Response Team (ERT) members, who are the experts in key programme and operational areas, were deployed 20 times for 783 days. Furthermore, the emergency simulation training was rolled out in mid-2015 with a total of 28 ERT and seven ERT members were trained and prepared for deployment as surge staff within 24-48 hours.- The UNICEF Emergency Programme Fond (EPF) which is a revolving fund that the organization disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis. In 2016, some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during the first ten months included:-2.2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (66 per cent of planned target);- 9.4 million children were vaccinated against measles (48 per cent of target);- 13.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (85 per cent of target);- 2.3 million children (70 per cent of target) recieved psycho-social support; and- 6.4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (81 per cent of target). Five major emergencies required organization-wide mobilization which included the continuing conflicts in South Sudan and Yemen; the escalating violence in Iraq; the protracted crisis in the Syrian Arab Republic and neighbouring refugee-hosting countries; and the unfolding humanitarian situation in north-east Nigeria. Regional offices were also responsible for overseeing the Central African Republic, Haiti and Lake Chad basin. In all cases, UNlCEF's infrastructure played a vital role in supporting country responses. Some of UNICEF's other achievements in 2016 include the following:1. The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was significantly enhanced with the recruitment of an additional ERT-members in 2016. Twelve ERT members undertook 37 missions to 17 countries and three regional offices, totaling 2,356 days between January and December 2016.2. Standby partners responded to a significant source of capacity, deploying 213 personnel to country offices in 2016 through agreements with 30 organizations. Forty-one per cent of these deployments supported Level 2 and Level 3 emergencies.3. UNICEF has prioritized strengthening its preparedness systems through the development of the Preparedness Procedure and associated guidance for country offices, including mandatory minimum standards. In addition, the new online Emergency Preparedness Platform has been designed to support planning and monitoring.4. UNICEF launched the Health Emergencies Preparedness Initiative to strengthen organizational capacity to respond predictably to public health emergencies, in close collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization. This initiative was a result of the lessons learnt from Ebola crisis.5. For the first time, in partnership with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and respective National Societies in 13 countrics, UNICEF developed joint programmes aimed at strengthening community resilience. Innovative tools such as U-Report are being used to engage communities and scale-up programmes.6. In an effort to strengthen capacity, UNICEF and the World Food Programme developed their first-ever joint Level 3 emergency response situation with 22 personnel from each agency. The exercise improved agencies' understandings of the mechanisms, policy and guidance to better prepare for deployment into a system-wide response.7. The Emergency Programme Fond - a revolving fond that UNICEF disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis, before donor resources are available - distributed USD 26 million to 14 country offices and three regional offices in 2016.The contribution to UNICEF cluring 2016 and from previous years has contributed to reaching some of the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts worldwide. In 2017, UNICEF and partners responded to 337 humanitarian situations of various scales in 102 countries. UNICEF focused its humanitarian action on saving lives, protecting rights and addressing the underlying causes of vulnerabilities to crises. More than half (55 per cent) of all country-level spending in 2017 supported humanitarian action. The organization continued to leverage its long-standing comparative advantage for humanitarian action of having a field presence before, during and after emergencies; delivering a multi-sector approach and collaborating various actors (e.g. government, civil society and the private sector). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF in 2017 include:- 3.0 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (83 per cent of planned target);- 18 million children were vaccinated against measles (74 percent of target);- 32.7 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (95 per cent of target);- 3.5 million children (89 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 8.8 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (73 per cent of target);- 46,000 children (81 percent of target) HIV-positive pregnant women continued anti-retroviral therapy; and- 1 million people benefitted from humanitarian cash transfers/cash-based support. There has been a good collaboration with UNICEF both through the focal points at UNICEF headquarters (people have changed during the four years) and EMOPS (Emergency Operations) where Manual Fontaine has been the head of unit. The contact person at Sida for UNICEF has been important for Sida HUM to liaise with and the person has changed during the four years. The contact with Swedish MFA has been handled by the Sida focal person mainly. The id number for the support was 5204046801 during 2014-2016 during which the old Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support led the work (2011-2016) and for 2017 when a new Humanitarian Strategy was in place the id number changed to 5204046802. The four narrative reports and financial reports under this contribution have been received in time. These include the Consolidated Emergency Reports/CERs (including the brief narrative of the Swedish contribution and Funds utilization reports (FUR), and Financial statement. UNICEF has repaid the balances from the annual support by sharing a letter the following year informing about the balance ans submitting the final financial report. The first repayment for 2013 and 2014 was reported on the previous support not part of these four years under this statement of conclusion (USD 193 820). The following repayments were reported on this contribution (October 2017, September 2019, and December 2019). The full balance of 8 401 990 SEK have thereby been accounted for by UNICEF and reflected in Planit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNICEF Humanitarian support to country programs 2014-2017

description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med UNICEF om bidrag till humanitära insatser för humanitära program 2014-2017, enligt insatsregeln 3.11.3. Beslutet gäller för ett fjärde och sista tilläggsår av ett ursprungligen 3-årigt avtal.
Sida förmedlar stöd till UNICEF baserat på FN appeller samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEFs humanitära program öronmärkt för aktiviteter på landnivå. Sida finansierar de humanitära appellerna per land enligt behoven som finns enligt UNICEFs handlingsplan (HAC) för varje kris. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en viktig aktör och genom detta stöd kommer organisationen att kunna fortsätta att ge livräddande stöd till de mest utsatta grupper som barn och kvinnor i humanitära krissituationer.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser för att stödja samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för barnskydd och könsbaserad våld. Stödet kommer att omfatta såväl nya akuta humanitära situationer som ännu inte har inträffat, som pågående eller eskalerande kriser.

Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik i form av att bygga upp lager i regionala depåer och en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, varvid UNICEF måste vara förberedda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida Humanitära Enheten har för närvarandet ett 3-årigt avtal med UNICEF. Avsikten med detta beslut är att förlänga nuvarande avtal med ett år som täcker perioden 2017 vilket kommer att vara det sista året under detta avtal. För år 2018 planeras ett nytt 4-årigt avtal med UNICEF i syfte att komma i fas med organisationens planerade strategiska plan för 2018-2021.

A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).

The full balance of 8 401 990 SEK have thereby been accounted for by UNICEF and reflected in Planit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNICEF Humanitarian support to country programs 2014-2017

description.narrative:
Detta beslut är ett kompletterande insatsbeslut till avtal med UNICEF om bidrag till humanitära insatser för humanitära program 2014-2017, enligt insatsregeln 3.11.3. Beslutet gäller för ett fjärde och sista tilläggsår av ett ursprungligen 3-årigt avtal.
Sida förmedlar stöd till UNICEF baserat på FN appeller samt UNICEFs ’Humanitarian Action for Children' (HAC). Bidraget kommer att allokeras till UNICEFs humanitära program öronmärkt för aktiviteter på landnivå. Sida finansierar de humanitära appellerna per land enligt behoven som finns enligt UNICEFs handlingsplan (HAC) för varje kris. Inom det humanitära systemet är UNICEF en viktig aktör och genom detta stöd kommer organisationen att kunna fortsätta att ge livräddande stöd till de mest utsatta grupper som barn och kvinnor i humanitära krissituationer.
Sidas stöd till UNICEF kommer att bidra med humanitär finansiering för att bistå utsatta grupper i humanitära kriser för att stödja samordnad och effektiv respons i de utvalda länderna. UNICEF ansvarar för att leda och samordna de globala klustren för nutrition, utbildning, vatten och sanitet samt har ansvar för barnskydd och könsbaserad våld. Stödet kommer att omfatta såväl nya akuta humanitära situationer som ännu inte har inträffat, som pågående eller eskalerande kriser.
UNICEF har framfört att tidig utbetalning av årliga bidrag för humanitära insatser är en förutsättning för att organisationen ska kunna ingå förpliktelser i sin tur i form av anställning av personal och kunna påbörja den upphandling av de varor och tjänster som behövs för programmen.Mot denna bakgrund gör Sida bedömningen att samtliga medel för projektet ska utbetalas omgående för att möjliggöra planering och uppstart av projektet till 1 januari 2017. Ett avsteg från Sidas vanliga rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
UNICEF har en väl utvecklad logistik i form av att bygga upp lager i regionala depåer och en roll i det humanitära systemet att även förse andra implementerande partners med varor. Humanitära kriser är till sin karaktär snabbt skiftande både geografiskt och i intensitet, varvid UNICEF måste vara förberedda att kunna flytta såväl personal som förnödenheter.
Sida Humanitära Enheten har för närvarandet ett 3-årigt avtal med UNICEF. Avsikten med detta beslut är att förlänga nuvarande avtal med ett år som täcker perioden 2017 vilket kommer att vara det sista året under detta avtal. För år 2018 planeras ett nytt 4-årigt avtal med UNICEF i syfte att komma i fas med organisationens planerade strategiska plan för 2018-2021.
Stödet till UNICEF för 2017 innefattar två kategorier:
A) Landspecifikt stöd: Den förslagna landfördelningen för 2017 (identifierade under allokeringsprocessen) omfattar totalt SEK 123 000 000 med stöd till UNICEFs humanitära arbete inom sektorerna hälsa, nutrition, utbildning, barnskyddsfrågor, könsbaserat våld och vatten och sanitet:
Icke-öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Syrien krisen SEK 30 000 000 2. Somalia SEK 9 000 000 3. Demokratiska Folk Republiken Korea SEK 5 000 000 4. Jemen SEK 17 000 000 5. Nigeria SEK 25 000 000 6. Libyen SEK 5 000 000 7. Irak SEK 14 000 000
Öronmärkt stöd föreslås till UNICEFs humanitära program enligt följande: 1. Etiopien SEK 15 000 000 (Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 2. Centralafrikanska republiken (CAR) SEK 3 000 000 (Rapid Response Mechanism/RRM)
B) Snabb responsmekanism i form av oallokerade medel: Genom detta avtalstillägg föreslås även ett stöd om SEK 59 000 000 för 2017 som UNICEF kan rekvirera och använda efter godkännande från Sida, för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser. UNICEF har föreslagit att dessa medel ska delvis (SEK 54 000 000) användas enligt följande:
1. Myanmarkrisen i Bangladesh SEK 5 000 000, 2. Somalia SEK 30 000 000, (öronmärkt för Hälsa, Nutrition, Vatten och sanitet) 3. Sudan SEK 9 000 000 samt 4. Sydsudan SEK 10 000 000
Responsen i de föreslagna kriser är i enlighet med UNICEFs HAC för dessa kontexter. Sida bedömer att behovet i dessa länder är stort och föreslår att stöd beslutas för att prioritera dessa kriser.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013 (när så är motiverat).
Under 2016 uppgick det totala utbetalda Sida bidraget till UNICEF till SEK 299 500 000. Den totala summan för åren 2014-2016 är SEK 668 300 000. Avtalet uppgår däremot till SEK 798 300 000 totalt vilket inkluderar ett regeringsbeslut (Afrika anslaget) på SEK 130 000 000 till Ebola insatsen under 2014.
Det totala bidraget som föreslås för 2017 uppgår därmed till SEK 182 000 000 (inklusive SEK 59 000 000 oallokerade medel för nya eller förvärrade humanitära kriser).
Humanitarian support to UNICEFs country programs during 2014-2017 in nutrition, health, child protection, WASH and emergency education.

The support has concerned a four year agreement period between UNICEF and Sida's humanitarian unit (HUM) for its humanitarian response to a number of prioritised crises between 2014-2017. The total Swedish contribution by Sida was 1 010 898 010 SEK during these four years. The objective during the four years has been to save lives and alleviate suffering for the most disadvantaged children in the world; in nutrition, health, water and sanitation and hygiene, as well as in emergency education, child protection and gender-based violence (GBV). During the first year of the agreement period (2014) also included funding directed to the ebola outbreak in West Africa.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Aid to Environment
Gender Equality
Participatory Development/Good Governance
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)
Trade Development

description.narrative: The support has concerned a four year period with the first three years (2014-2016) upheld through the Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support 2011-2016 and the final fourth year (2017) being part of the new strategy for the period 2017-2021). The majority of Sida HUM's contribution has been for the UNICEF HAC:s (Humanitarian Assistance for Children) and have been treated as humanitarian country programme funds (unearmarked) while a few programmes have been earmarket to ceratin thematic areas within the HAC:s. The prioritisation has been led by Sida HUM through its HCA (Humanitarian Crises Analysis) processes on an annual basis. UNICEF provides annual CER:s reporting for each context on a country basis reporting on what has been achieved compared to each HAC. In addition to that Sida receives the global humanitarian annual report of UNICEF and a two-pager for each financed context for a more detailed information on what exactly the Swedish funds have been directed to. For 2014, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 177.5 MSEK which contributed to some of the following worldwide humanitarian results (as per the annual global humanitarian report):- 1.8 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (70 per cent of planned target);- 16 million children were vaccinated against measles (81 percent of target);- 13 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (77 per cent oftarget);- 1.8 million children (66 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 2 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (58 per cent oftarget); and- With the Ebola outbreak in 2014, some of UNlCEF'S achievements included: established and supported morethan 50 Community Care Centres and rapid isolation facilities with a bed capacity of 500; 30 000 children affectedby the outbreak beneitted from psycho-social support; 4 100 metric tonnes (MT) of Ebola related commoditieswere shipped; more than 50 000 community volunteers, health workers, religious Ieaders and youth weremobilized; 1 400 Community Watch Committees were established; and 1 million children received educationthrough remote programming while schools were closed. Support from Sida has contributed to reaching the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts in the world. For 2015, Sida financed UNICEF's humanitarian programmes with the total amount of 184 MSEK. Sida supported UNICEF with funding of 16 countries and one region (i.e the floods in Malawi and Mozambique, earthquake in Nepal and the deteriorating situations in CAR, South Sudan, Yemen, Syria, Nigeria and Iraq). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during 2015 for which the Swedish financing has contributed towards are:- 2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (69 per cent of planned target);- 1.3 million children were vaccinated against measles (62 per cent of target);- 22.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing andcooking (94 per cent of target);- 2 million children (74 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal andinformal (45 per cent of target); and- Since the Ebola outbreak in 2014, UNICEF'S achievements in Sierra Leone. Liberiaand Guinea included:- 191,200 children received psychosocial support;- More than 3.6 million households were reached with interpersonal communications and skills training on Ebola prevention;- More than 8,000 metric tonnes of supplies delivered in the largest supply operations in UNlCEF'S history; and- 64 community care centres were established.Some of UNICEF'S other achievments in 2015 include the following:- The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was enhanced by recruiting eight Emergency Response Team (ERI) members. In total, 12 field offices were supported by this team with some 500 days of ERT deployments throughout the year.- UNICEF's lmmediate Response Team (ERT) members, who are the experts in key programme and operational areas, were deployed 20 times for 783 days. Furthermore, the emergency simulation training was rolled out in mid-2015 with a total of 28 ERT and seven ERT members were trained and prepared for deployment as surge staff within 24-48 hours.- The UNICEF Emergency Programme Fond (EPF) which is a revolving fund that the organization disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis. In 2016, some of the global results achieved by UNICEF during the first ten months included:-2.2 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (66 per cent of planned target);- 9.4 million children were vaccinated against measles (48 per cent of target);- 13.6 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (85 per cent of target);- 2.3 million children (70 per cent of target) recieved psycho-social support; and- 6.4 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (81 per cent of target). Five major emergencies required organization-wide mobilization which included the continuing conflicts in South Sudan and Yemen; the escalating violence in Iraq; the protracted crisis in the Syrian Arab Republic and neighbouring refugee-hosting countries; and the unfolding humanitarian situation in north-east Nigeria. Regional offices were also responsible for overseeing the Central African Republic, Haiti and Lake Chad basin. In all cases, UNlCEF's infrastructure played a vital role in supporting country responses. Some of UNICEF's other achievements in 2016 include the following:1. The capacity to rapidly deploy staff with specialized skills in emergency coordination, programming and operations was significantly enhanced with the recruitment of an additional ERT-members in 2016. Twelve ERT members undertook 37 missions to 17 countries and three regional offices, totaling 2,356 days between January and December 2016.2. Standby partners responded to a significant source of capacity, deploying 213 personnel to country offices in 2016 through agreements with 30 organizations. Forty-one per cent of these deployments supported Level 2 and Level 3 emergencies.3. UNICEF has prioritized strengthening its preparedness systems through the development of the Preparedness Procedure and associated guidance for country offices, including mandatory minimum standards. In addition, the new online Emergency Preparedness Platform has been designed to support planning and monitoring.4. UNICEF launched the Health Emergencies Preparedness Initiative to strengthen organizational capacity to respond predictably to public health emergencies, in close collaboration with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization. This initiative was a result of the lessons learnt from Ebola crisis.5. For the first time, in partnership with the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and respective National Societies in 13 countrics, UNICEF developed joint programmes aimed at strengthening community resilience. Innovative tools such as U-Report are being used to engage communities and scale-up programmes.6. In an effort to strengthen capacity, UNICEF and the World Food Programme developed their first-ever joint Level 3 emergency response situation with 22 personnel from each agency. The exercise improved agencies' understandings of the mechanisms, policy and guidance to better prepare for deployment into a system-wide response.7. The Emergency Programme Fond - a revolving fond that UNICEF disburses to field offices within 48 hours of a sudden humanitarian crisis, before donor resources are available - distributed USD 26 million to 14 country offices and three regional offices in 2016.The contribution to UNICEF cluring 2016 and from previous years has contributed to reaching some of the most vulnerable populations in some of the most challenging contexts worldwide. In 2017, UNICEF and partners responded to 337 humanitarian situations of various scales in 102 countries. UNICEF focused its humanitarian action on saving lives, protecting rights and addressing the underlying causes of vulnerabilities to crises. More than half (55 per cent) of all country-level spending in 2017 supported humanitarian action. The organization continued to leverage its long-standing comparative advantage for humanitarian action of having a field presence before, during and after emergencies; delivering a multi-sector approach and collaborating various actors (e.g. government, civil society and the private sector). Some of the global results achieved by UNICEF in 2017 include:- 3.0 million children treated for severe acute malnutrition (83 per cent of planned target);- 18 million children were vaccinated against measles (74 percent of target);- 32.7 million people were provided with access to safe water for drinking, bathing and cooking (95 per cent of target);- 3.5 million children (89 percent of target) received psycho-social support;- 8.8 million children were provided with access to improved education, both formal and informal (73 per cent of target);- 46,000 children (81 percent of target) HIV-positive pregnant women continued anti-retroviral therapy; and- 1 million people benefitted from humanitarian cash transfers/cash-based support. There has been a good collaboration with UNICEF both through the focal points at UNICEF headquarters (people have changed during the four years) and EMOPS (Emergency Operations) where Manual Fontaine has been the head of unit. The contact person at Sida for UNICEF has been important for Sida HUM to liaise with and the person has changed during the four years. The contact with Swedish MFA has been handled by the Sida focal person mainly. The id number for the support was 5204046801 during 2014-2016 during which the old Swedish Strategy for Humanitarian support led the work (2011-2016) and for 2017 when a new Humanitarian Strategy was in place the id number changed to 5204046802. The four narrative reports and financial reports under this contribution have been received in time. These include the Consolidated Emergency Reports/CERs (including the brief narrative of the Swedish contribution and Funds utilization reports (FUR), and Financial statement. UNICEF has repaid the balances from the annual support by sharing a letter the following year informing about the balance ans submitting the final financial report. The first repayment for 2013 and 2014 was reported on the previous support not part of these four years under this statement of conclusion (USD 193 820). The following repayments were reported on this contribution (October 2017, September 2019, and December 2019). The full balance of 8 401 990 SEK have thereby been accounted for by UNICEF and reflected in Planit.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
